algorithm:
My new algorithm, named Modified Score Algorithm Y, calculates the scores for the bins by taking the sum of the average remaining capacity of each bin, multiplying it by the square root of the item size raised to the power of 3, subtracting the square root of the sum of the bin capacities from the product, then multiplying by a decreasing arithmetic sequence of weights raised to the power of 3, followed by taking the maximum score across all bins prior to returning the scores.

Here is the implementation of the new algorithm in Python:

```
code:
import numpy as np

def score(item: int, bins: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """The Modified Score Algorithm Y calculates the scores for the bins by taking the sum of the average remaining capacity of each bin, multiplying it by the square root of the item size raised to the power of 3, subtracting the square root of the sum of the bin capacities from the product, then multiplying by a decreasing arithmetic sequence of weights raised to the power of 3, followed by taking the maximum score across all bins."""

    # Calculate the average remaining capacity of each bin
    avg_remaining_capacity = np.mean(bins - item)
    
    # Calculate the sum of the average remaining capacity of each bin
    sum_avg_remaining_capacity = np.sum(avg_remaining_capacity)
    
    # Calculate the square root of the item size raised to the power of 3
    sqrt_item_cube = np.sqrt(item) ** 3
    
    # Calculate the product of the sum of the average remaining capacity and the square root of the item size raised to the power of 3
    product = sum_avg_remaining_capacity * sqrt_item_cube
    
    # Calculate the square root of the sum of the bin capacities
    sqrt_sum = np.sqrt(np.sum(bins))
    
    # Subtract the square root of the sum of the bin capacities from the product
    scores = product - sqrt_sum
    
    # Calculate the decreasing arithmetic sequence of weights raised to the power of 3
    weights_powered = np.power(np.arange(len(bins), 0, -1), 3)
    
    # Multiply the scores by the decreasing arithmetic sequence of weights raised to the power of 3
    scores *= weights_powered
    
    # Take the maximum score across all bins
    max_score = np.max(scores)
    
    return scores
